data: A large rectangular block of shell-bearing limestone, intact on top, left, right and behind, but damaged below. Appears intact lower right underside, so the only significant loss/damage is the lower left corner. The left edge of the stone is clearly preserved, which implies at least one additional block originally stood to the left.
Two lines of large Latin letters, with a slight vacat above, filling the width of the stone.
Found in 1925 in material to the east of the 'Oratory of Phalaris' (Marconi writes "ritrovata tra le macerie a oriente del tempietto")
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo Regionale Archeologico Pietro Griffo
Comprehensive collection of archaeological material discovered at the site of Agrigento and in Agrigento province, organised both by chronology and type across a number of rooms and corridors
Contrada San Nicola, 12 Valley of the Temples, 92100 - Agrigento (AG)
Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae

T. Mommsen, Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae, Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum, consilio et auctoritate Academiae Litterarum Regiae Borussicae editum, 10.2 (Berlin: G. Reimer, 1883)
Architettura civile in Agrigento ellenistico-romana e rapporti con l'Anatolia

E. De Miro, «Architettura civile in Agrigento ellenistico-romana e rapporti con l’Anatolia», Quaderni dell’Istituto di Archeologia della Facolta di Lettere e Filosofia dell’Universita di Messina 3 (1988): 63–72
Sicily under the Roman Empire: the archaeology of a Roman province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535
R.J.A. Wilson, Sicily under the Roman Empire: The Archaeology of a Roman Province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535 (Warminster: Aris and Philips, 1990)

Accademia nazionale dei Lincei, Istituto nazionale di archeologia e storia dell’arte (Italy), e Reale Accademia d’Italia, «Notizie degli scavi di antichità», Notizie degli Scavi di Antichità, 1876, http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1646037
Agrigento. I.I santuari urbani : l'area sacra tra il Tempio di Zeus e Porta V
E. De Miro, Agrigento. I.I santuari urbani : l’area sacra tra il Tempio di Zeus e Porta V (Rome: L’Erma di Bretschneider, 2000)
Architettura pubblica ed evergetismo nella Sicilia di età repubblicana

Lorenzo Campagna, «Architettura pubblica ed evergetismo nella Sicilia di età repubblicana», in La Sicilia romana tra Repubblica e Alto Impero, a c. di C. Miccichè, S. Modeo, e L. Santagati (Caltanissetta: Siciliantica, 2007), 110–34
De Miro, 1988, Architettura civile in Agrigento ellenistico-romana e rapporti con l'Anatolia
Wilson, 1990, Sicily under the Roman Empire: the archaeology of a Roman province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535
Marconi, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità
De Miro, 2000, Agrigento. I.I santuari urbani : l'area sacra tra il Tempio di Zeus e Porta V
Campagna, 2007, Architettura pubblica ed evergetismo nella Sicilia di età repubblicana
ISic000616. A Roman honours his mother

1[---]us · M(arci) · f(ilius) ·Ter(etina tribu) · (vac.1)Pius
2[---].f̣(iliam) · matrem · suam ·

1[---]USMFTER  PIUS
2[---]·.MATREMSUAM

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text from autopsy;
  • line.2: [devo]TE, De Miro 2000; the first letter preserves part of an upper horizontal, the second is either an E or an F

English translation

[---]us Pius, son of Marcus, of the tribe Teretina

Italian translation

[---]us Pius figlio di Marco della tribù Teretina [---] sua madre

commentary

The surviving traces at the start of line two are most readily compatible in the context with TF, which would be T(iberi) f(iliam) as the filiation of the honoured mother's name. The suggestion of De Miro to read devote is less plausible. De Miro's suggestion to read ter pius as 'thrice pius' rather than tribal and cognomen/epithet cannot be followed. The first part of the text continued on another block to the left. The interpunct after 'suam' in line 2 and the edge of the stone suggest this is the right hand end of the text. The layout could imply another line below on another block, perhaps containing the explanation for the honours. It has been generally assumed that the stone belongs to the so-called 'Oratory of Phalaris', which in turn was suggested by the excavator Marconi (1926) to be a heroon. The idea that it was a tomb or heroon, rather than a temple was firmly rejected by Wilson (1990: 31 and 356 n.102). Campagna (2007) has however rightly questioned whether there is in fact any evidence for the association. The block is the same stone as the temple; it does however show no traces of the stucco which covers much of the exterior of the temple. The formulation of nominative individual and then accusative for the mother makes it more likely that this is an honorific (perhaps a statue base?) rather than a funerary inscription, albeit using the Greek accusative for the honorand (Latin would ordinarily use a dative) - this latter feature could either imply a Roman / Italian immigrant to the island or else a 'romanised' Sicilian. Honours of this sort for a woman in Latin epigraphy at this date are rare.

  • De Miro 1988 67-69 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002052
  • Wilson 1990 356 n.97, 31 n.102 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001509
  • De Miro 2000 95-6, esp. n.160 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002050
  • Campagna 2007 119 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002096

A Roman honours his mother Jonathan Prag Jonathan Prag John Fell OUP Research Fund ERC Advanced Grant no.885040 Jonathan Prag original data collection and editing James Cummings conversion to EpiDoc James Chartrand site construction and encoding Valeria Vitale editing of geo data Michael Metcalfe museum data collection Simona Stoyanova standardisation of template and tidying up encoding system automated or batch processes I.Sicily ISic000616 491463 129884 26201044 http://sicily.classics.ox.ac.uk/inscription/ISic000616 10.5281/zenodo.4338095 Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence. Italy Sicily Agrigento Museo Regionale Archeologico Pietro Griffo S.2319 Latin

A large rectangular block of shell-bearing limestone, intact on top, left, right and behind, but damaged below. Appears intact lower right underside, so the only significant loss/damage is the lower left corner. The left edge of the stone is clearly preserved, which implies at least one additional block originally stood to the left.

block 36.5 139.5 20.5 Two lines of large Latin letters, with a slight vacat above, filling the width of the stone. chiselled Plain broad Latin letters of the Republican style without serifs. P and R are closed; E has all three bars of equal length; M is open, with the mid-point not always descending to the lower line; S is somewhat flat at top and bottom. Simple triangular interpuncts between words. Line 1 90-105 Line 2 85-95 Interlineation line 1 to 2 30-45 Agrigentum Agrigento 37.32084, 13.58876 Republican (letter forms), perhaps 125—75 BCE Found in 1925 in material to the east of the 'Oratory of Phalaris' (Marconi writes "ritrovata tra le macerie a oriente del tempietto")37.296666, 13.588604 On display. 2018.07.17 Prag

Text from autopsy [devo]TE, De Miro 2000; the first letter preserves part of an upper horizontal, the second is either an E or an F

[---]us Pius, son of Marcus, of the tribe Teretina

[---]us Pius figlio di Marco della tribù Teretina [---] sua madre
